In this review, we provide a comprehensive overview of the MoS2 nanomaterials, summarizing recent related studies on structures, properties, synthesis techniques and recent progress on hydrogen evolution reaction (HER). Base on its crystalline anisotropy arising from the sandwiched structure of S–Mo–S layers, four poly-types of MoS2 structures have been identified, viz. 1T MoS2, 1H MoS2, 2H MoS2 and 3R MoS2. After their structures investigated, we summarized its diverse properties, such as activity, friction, cat-
oS2 tructures roperties ynthesis ER
alytic, optical and electronic properties. Next, we describe the general synthetic approaches, viz. physical and chemical methods, also address future directions for various practical applications of novel MoS2based materials. Some key recent progress on HER are addressed, which are substantiated by examples from the existing literature and some new results. Finally, suggestions for future MoS2 based catalyst designs for HER are given.

. Introduction
Since the discovery of fullerenes in 1985 [1], it was soon recgnized that other inorganic layered materials, such as MoS2 ould also form fullerene-like structures as reported in Refs. [2,3]. fter the discovery of helical microtubules of graphitic carbon in 991 [4], other inorganic nanotubes analogous to carbon nanoubes were prepared and characterized, such as MoS2, which is llustrated as an archetypal example. Sometime, layered MoS2 suported on carbon nanotubes and formed as MoS2 nanotubes [5,6]; therwise, the pure MoS2 nanotube formed from self-assembly rocess or a catalyzed thermal decomposition of (NH4)2MoS4 [7–9]. ith the discovery and characterization of graphene in recent ears [6,10–13], which has generated great interest in this twoimensional nano-carbon sheet, it would seem natural to explore he synthesis of graphene analogues of layered inorganic materils. Single-layer or multilayer MoS2 has been investigated as an rchetypal example [14–20]. Molybdenum disulfide (MoS2), a crysal consisting of weakly coupled layers of S–Mo–S where a Mo atom ayer is sandwiched by two layers of S atoms, offers a large direct xperimental band gap of around 1.8 eV. After many years’ research, our poly-types of MoS2 structures have been identified, viz. 1T
oS2, 1H MoS2, 2H MoS2 and 3R MoS2. Of these, the 1T MoS2 and R MoS2 are meta-stable and the 1H phase is the most stable among ll the poly-types. The 1T MoS2 has the molybdenum atoms coorinated octahedrally by the sulfur and molybdenum atoms to form unit cell. Their ball and stick model of the structures will be preented in the sections following. 1H phase (the basic unit of MoS2 onolayer) has the molybdenum atoms coordinated octahedrally y the sulfur atoms and sandwiched in layers of S–Mo–S. 2H MoS2 as trigonal prismatic coordination around the molybdenum atom nd with two S–Mo–S units per elemental cell. The 3R MoS2 also as trigonal primatic coordination, the same as the 2H MoS2 but ith three S-Mo-S units per elemental cell arranged along the cxis direction. These arrangements are shown schematically in this eview.
The molybdenum disulfide (MoS2) is a naturally occurring layred solid that finds applications in industry in both its bulk and ispersed forms. Similar to the graphene layers in graphite, indiidual sandwiched S–Mo–S layers are assembled together by weak an der Waals interactions in hexagonally packed structures. These ayers could move relatively easily against each other, which makes
oS2 as a widely used dry lubricant. Due the large band-edge exciation of the metal centered d–d transition that gives rise to unique lectronic features, it is therefore used in numerous applications

such as in hydrogen evolution reaction catalysis, electrochemical intercalation, hydrogen storage, elastic and coating materials in Li batteries.
In this review, we provide a comprehensive overview of the MoS2, summarizing recent related studies on structures, properties and synthesis techniques. First, we divide the MoS2 nanostructures into four poly-types, and investigate their structures. The anisotropy in properties such as the anisotropic electronic conductivity resulting from the crystalline anisotropy of the individual sandwiched S–Mo–S layers and its diverse properties, such as activity, friction, catalytic, optical and electronic properties will be discussed. Next, we describe the general synthetic approaches using physical and chemical methods. Particular emphasis will also be given to their fabrication methods along with their various chemical/physical properties and applications. And then, some key recent progress and perspectives for future research on MoS2based materials using in hydrogen evolution reaction are also covered. We hope that this review will assist and inspire in further developments of MoS2-based materials and devices.
2. Structures and properties
2.1. Structures
Molybdenum disulfide (MoS2) has a crystal structure consisting of weakly coupled layers of S–Mo–S, where a Mo atom layer is sandwiched between two layers of S atoms. It offers a large direct band gap found experimentally to be around 1.8 eV. Crystals of MoS2 are composed of vertically stacked, weakly interacting layers held together by van der Waals interactions (Fig. 1a) [21–23]. As seen in the Figure, the neighboring planes in bulk MoS2 are held together by weak van der Waals forces, making it possible to produce monolayers of MoS2 using the well-established micromechanical cleavage and liquid exfoliation techniques [22]. A single layer, 6.5 Å thick (Fig. 1a), was extracted using scotch tape or lithium-based intercalation [22–24]. Fig. 1b depicts the covalently bonded S–Mo–S unit cell of MoS2 arranged in a hexagonal lattice with each sulfur atom coordinated with three molybdenum atoms within a single layer of MoS2. The Mo–S bond is 2.42 Å in length and the optimized lattice constant of MoS2 monolayer is 3.18 Å in thickness, which is consistent with the many previous predictions [22–24]. The adsorption of ad-atoms is a widely used and efficient way to introduce new functionalities in nanoscale applications. The different ad-atoms used are C [10,25,26], B [27], Au [28–30], Mo [31], Cr [32,33], Pt [34], Pd [34], Ag [34], Rh [35], Ti [29,36], Fe [37,38], Co [39–41], Ni

Based on many years’ research, four poly-types of MoS2 have een described. They are 1T MoS2, 1H MoS2, 2H MoS2 and 3R MoS2 45]. Of these, the 1H phase is the most stable among all poly-types, nd the 1T MoS2 and 3R MoS2 are meta-stable Schematic drawing f these common poly-types for MoS2 are shown in Fig. 2. The 1T oS2 has the molybdenum atoms coordinated octahedrally by the ulfur atoms to form a unit cell; 1H phase (the basic unit of MoS2 onolayer) has the molybdenum atoms coordinated octahedrally y the sulfur atoms and sandwiched in the form of S–Mo–S; 2H oS2 has trigonal prismatic coordination around the molybdenum tom with two S–Mo–S units per elemental cell; The 3R MoS2 also as the same trigonal primatic coordination as the 2H MoS2 but ith three S–Mo–S units per elemental cell along the c-axis direcion. In the case of lithium deposition on a single crystal of MoS2 at oom temperature, the lithium atom is intercalated into the MoS2. wo reactions take place: (a) an intercalation reaction according to he rigid band model and (b) an intercalation reaction accompanied y a phase transition from 1H or 2H to 1T. This transformation is aused by the electron transfer from the alkali metal to the d orbital f the transition metal center, which results in the metallic-like haracter of the material and causing destabilization of the lattices elated to the diffusion of the lithium atom [46–48]. More details f these poly-types will describe next in this part.
.1.1. 1H MoS2
The Mo metal atom, in a six-fold coordination environment, is exagonally packed between two trigonal atomic layers of S atoms. epending on the S atom arrangement, the metal atom can be oordinated by six S atoms in either trigonal prismatic (1H) or an

octahedral (1T) arrangement. The 1H poly-type with trigonal prismatic coordination is the most stable among all poly-types [49,50]. As the 1H phase is more stable than the 1T phase, only the 1H phase MoS2 monolayer will be considered in this section. As shown in Fig. 1b, the upper panel and the lower panel are respectively, the top view and the side view of MoS2 monolayer [10,44]. For the 1H phase, the basic unit of the MoS2 monolayer is composed of a molybdenum atom coordinated with six sulfur atoms. It is organized into two layers of sulfur atoms forming a sandwich structure, with a layer of molybdenum atoms in the middle, and the S atoms in the upper layer are located directly above those on the lower layer as shown in Fig. 2.

2.2. Properties
Molybdenum disulfide MoS2 is a naturally occurring layered solid that finds applications in industry in both its bulk and dispersed forms. Similar to the graphene layers in graphite, individual sandwiched S–Mo–S layers are held together by the weak van der Waals interactions in hexagonally packed structures. The ability of these layers to move relatively easily against each other makes MoS2 an important tribomaterial. This crystalline anisotropy results in anisotropy in properties such as electronic conductivity and finds applications as catalysts, batteries and lubricants. Also MoS2-based composites are being utilized for its optical, electrical and catalytic properties [75].
2.2.1. Activity It is well known that MoS2 could be used as a reservoir of both electric charge and chemical species in the intercalation and transportation processes. Nevertheless, this sulfide acts as a rather chemically inert substance [78]. Thus, using a standard solution of hydrochloric acid, nitric acid or sulfuric acid leads to very little etching of the surface after a normal etching time [45]. Only a solution of sulfuric acid with potassium dichromate was found to create large and deep defects on the MoS2 (0 0 0 1) faces [78]. MoS2 is also stable against photo-corrosion, which could be useful for photo-electrochemical applications. It was widely accepted that the predominant active sites of MoS2 are metallic edge planes with sulfur vacancies, whereas the basal plane, normally with completely coordinated sulfur atoms, is basically inert [79,80]. All the chemical processes take place on the sulfur atoms of the MoS2 structure with no direct interaction with the Mo atoms. This interesting chemistry was associated with the metallic edge states of the MoS2 nanocrystals, since there is no indication of chemical activity, experimentally or theoretically, at the S atoms on the basal plane of the MoS2 structures. The metallic states associated with S atoms at the edges, on the other hand, have the ability to donate and accept electrons and thus act as catalytic sites just like ordinary metal surfaces [81]. Lauritsen et al. reported extraordinary chemical properties associated with the edges of two-dimensional MoS2 nanoclusters, which have proved to be able to hydrogenate and break up thiophene (C4H4S) molecules [82]. After the first C˛ S bond in thiophene is broken, the sulfur is much more reactive and the final extrusion may take place at another site on the cluster to complete the hydrodesulfurization process. MoS2 can be used to clean up sulfur-containing molecules from oil products in the hydrodesulfurization process [82].

Individual snapshots of the simulations are shown in Fig. 13, several remarkable trends could be found: the strain–stress relation is steeper for smaller nanotubes, which was in agreement with the well-known inverse proportionality of the tube energy with respect to its diameter [8,92]. Normalized to the tube diameter, the tubes show nearly the same slope, which means that the strain–stress relation is essentially independent of the tube’s chirality. In contrast to tensile strain–stress curves, the systems deviate from linearity toward higher stress values; that is, if the system is deformed, it gets harder to deform further and gets even stronger. .2.3. Catalytic properties Molybdenum disulfide, in its various forms is of great interest
n several catalytic reactions. The importance of MoS2 as a catalyst s not only based on its relatively high activity, which for a given rocess could not be as large as the other metallic derivatives, but lso on its resistance to poisoning with sulfur [80,101–103]. The atalytic properties of the molybdenum sulfide are, as mentioned bove, closely related to the structural properties of the material. esearch in this area has been mainly focused on two kinds of rocesses: electrochemical processes and photochemical processes nvolved in hydrodesulfurization (HDS) activity and hydrogen evoution ability. Electrochemical studies show that the former occurs n the absence of light at centers located in the plane parallel to he c-axis, while the photoreactions occur on the van der Waals lanes [104]. This is probably because the contributions of the nononding orbitals dz2 or antibonding dz2–pz orbitals, forming the alence band, are located toward the van der Waals surface, while he orbitals which form the conduction band (dx2–y2, dxy, dxz , dyz nd npy) are oriented towards the surface parallel to the c-axis [45].
MoS2-based catalysts have been widely used as hydrodesulfurzation (HDS) catalysts for several decades [81,105–107]. HDS of oil ractions is an important refining process, the importance is related o the increased demand to convert heavier and more sulfur-rich eed stocks and to the need of make oil products more envionmentally acceptable by reducing the sulfur content [108,109]. onsequently, there is a demand for introducing so-called deep DS, which will require new processing schemes and more active

catalysts. In order to catch the development of new HDS catalysts, several useful structure activity relationships have been established for both unpromoted and promoted catalysts [106]. Commercial HDS catalysts consist of MoS2 nanoclusters well dispersed on alumina foil or on a supporting film and promoted by cobalt or nickel atoms. The activity of unpromoted catalysts is attributed to the active sites located at the edges of the MoS2 nanoclusters, where they play an important role in the HDS process. For promoted catalysts, Co–Mo–S and Ni–Mo–S structures have been proved to be mainly responsible for the HDS activity [81]. For all these systems and for transition metal sulfides in general, the metal-sulfur binding energy has been suggested to be one of the key parameters determining the activity, even though the specific role of the sulfur binding energy varies in the different studies [106,110]. It is generally believed that pristine HDS catalysts will be unable to adsorb the sulfur-containing molecules, and that sulfur vacancies must be formed to provide catalytic active sites. Therefore the amount of sulfur vacancies is a key measure of the catalytic activity, that is closely correlated to the sulfur binding energy [106].
MoS2 also could serve as a promising electrocatalyst for the electrochemical hydrogen evolution reaction (HER). There have been many computational and experimental results confirming the HER activity stemming from the sulfur edges of MoS2 plates, while their basal planes were catalytically inert [111–114]. As a result, nanosized MoS2 nanostructures with exposed edges will be more active for HER electrocatalysis than MoS2 in bulk forms. Recently, MoS2 catalysts supported on activated carbon [112], Au [113], carbon paper [114], Pt [115] and graphene [111] were prepared by physical vapor deposition or annealing molybdate in H2S. Three main techniques have been proved successfully to optimize the HER activity of MoS2, including (1) increasing the catalytic activity of the active sites, (2) improving the electrical contact to these sites, and (3) increasing the number of active sites of the catalysts [116,117].
Exfoliated MoS2 catalysts could also be used in hydrogenation of CO and in methanation [118]. The single molecular layers of MoS2 are deposited onto a large surface area doped with a nickel ions. The most active species appears to be an oxisulfide, even in the absence of nickel as the promoter. Catalysts prepared by the exfoliation process offer excellent catalytic performance [119]. Such a decrease in nergy at not only results in an increase of the band gap but also hanges its nature from indirect (as in the bulk) to direct bandgap. his change in character presents an interesting opportunity for ngineering the electronic properties of layered MoS2 composites s a function of interlayer separation and/or number of layers.
Absorption and photoluminescence spectra of MoS2 thin films nnealed at various temperatures were studied by Eda et al. (Fig. 15) 123]. As-deposited sputtered films exhibit no clear characterisic peaks of pristine 2H-MoS2 except for the high energy excitonic eatures in the near-UV range (200–300 nm). It does not exhibit hotoluminescence, as expected from their partial metallic charcter. With increasing annealing temperature, the characteristic oS2 excitonic features emerge and grow in intensity. Emergence f these features indicates restoration of 2H phase upon annealing. ompared to the pristine mechanically exfoliated monolayer, the xciton peaks are less resolved, suggesting the presence of residual tructural disorder, probably owing to remnant lattice distortion 49]. Reduced absorption in the near-IR region, which is below he band gap of 2H-MoS2, also suggests reduction of the metallic T phase component. By the way, annealed films exhibit reproucible photoluminescence when their thickness is sufficiently
ls Today 3 (2016) 23–56 35
low (<5 nm). A two-dimensional crystal of monolayer molybdenum disulfide (MoS2) gives photoluminescence evident of the direct gap semiconductor in striking contrast to its bulk counterpart. Fig. 15b shows the photoluminescence spectra of a thin (∼1.3 nm) and a thick (∼10 nm) film after annealing at different temperatures. For direct comparison, gradual increase in the emission intensity with annealing temperature is observed for the thinner film while no emission is observed from the thicker film even after annealing. The emission spectrum for the thin film consists of one major peak and one minor peak at around 660 and 610 nm, respectively. These peaks, labeled as A and B, agree well with the energy of A and B excitons, suggesting that they are from the direct band gap photoluminescence from the K point. Increase in film thickness was found to result in a slight red shift in both the absorption resonance and photoluminescence energy (Fig. 15c and d). The shift is small (∼20 meV) but consistent with the fact that direct gap is only weakly sensitive to the confinement effect due to the large electron and hole mass around the K point, changing by only 20 meV between mono- and bilayer MoS2 [123]. Fig. 15d shows that the thinnest sample exhibits the strongest photoluminescence while the emission intensity gradually decreases with increasing film thickness. The gradual quenching of photoluminescence with film thickness is in contrast to that in mechanically exfoliated MoS2 where the quantum yield drops rapidly from monolayer to bilayer [123]. The thickness-dependent electronic structure and the unique two-phase behavior of MoS2 reveal unusual versatility of this material. For example, the properties of metallic and semitransparent 1T-MoS2 represent new opportunities in the development of transparent conductors. These features of chemically exfoliated MoS2 make them attractive for novel electronic and optoelectronic devices such as nonvolatile memory, solar cells, and light-emitting diodes.
3. Synthesis techniques
Many routes have been applied to the synthesis MoS2 nanostructures, that could be divided into two general synthetic approaches: (1) physical and (2) chemical methods. Physical methods usually involve high-energy techniques such as microwave plasma, laser ablation, arc discharge, sputtering technique or pulsed-laser deposition, which are rapid. But the MoS2 nanostructures obtained are sparse and tend to aggregate, which may reduce surface areas and preclude further functionalization or dispersion. Chemical routes had been reported using a wide range of methods, including metal-organic chemical vapor deposition; high-temperature transport, decomposition or annealing strategies, solvothermal and sonochemical synthesis [131]. In this section on synthesis, we present a typical procedure and show representative transmission electron microscopy (TEM) or scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images to give a direct impression of how these nanomaterials normally appear. Furthermore, for detailed instructions on each type of synthesis, the readers could refer to the corresponding references.
3.1. Physical methods
3.1.1. Microwave plasma The microwave plasma process, originally developed for the synthesis of oxide and nitride nanoparticles, was used to synthesize the specimen. In the plasma reaction a quartz tube acts a monomode microwave cavity. The Mo(CO)6 used as precursors was vaporized outside of the reaction zone and introduced into the reaction gas in front of the plasma zone, where the nanoparticles are formed. 3.2. Chemical methods
3.2.1. chemical vapor deposition Chemical vapor deposition (CVD) has proved to be one of the most practical methods for synthesizing layered materials such as large-area graphene and graphene analogues. The sulfurization of MoO3, MoCl5, MoF6 or metal-organic precursors (such as Mo(S-t-Bu)4, Mo(CO)6) using the CVD method has been adopted to synthesize MoS2 materials on various substrates such as Si, SiO2, Al2O3, Cr, Au, Au/Cr bi-layer and sapphire [150–157]. It is known that closed caged structures are thermodynamically more stable than isolated lamellae-like structures at high temperatures. Hence, Etzkorn et al. studied the influence of temperature on samples prepared by metal-organic chemical vapor deposition (MOCVD) [153]. The results show that high temperatures thermal treatments increase the order within the nanoparticles. MoS2 yielded fullerene-like particles at 700 ◦C and incompletely closed round particles at 800 ◦C as shown in Fig. 22. Zhan et al. demonstrated a direct preparation of single- and few-layered MoS2 on SiO2 substrates using pre-deposited Mo film followed by a CVD method [154]. The as-prepared samples can either be readily utilized for further device fabrication or be easily released from SiO2 and transferred to other arbitrary substrates as shown in Fig. 23c. 3.3. Other methods
Substantial efforts have been devoted to prepare 2D thin-layer MoS2, including scotch tape based micromechanical exfoliation, intercalation assisted exfoliation, liquid exfoliation, physical vapor deposition, hydrothermal synthesis, micro-domain reaction or nanocasting approach and thermolysis of single precursor containing Mo and S [56,61,117,205–211]. However, the traditional mechanical exfoliation method is still employed to obtain the MoS2 atomic layer with rather modest foot-print, limiting its commercial usefulness. Liquid exfoliation of layered materials including MoS2 has been proposed to be a promising large-scale synthesis method for a 2D nano-sheet. Although it is quite facile to create hybrid dispersions or composites using this method, its application into device applications still needs further development. Other methods, including hydrothermal methods that were employed to synthesize MoS2 nanosheet have similar limitations.

4.2. MoS2 and their composite as electrocatalyst for HER
4.2.1. Overview of MoS2 electrochemical HER Electrical catalytic HER performance of MoS2 and their composite is currently limited by the density and reactivity of active sites, poor electrical transport, and inefficient electrical contact to the catalyst. It has become possible to anchor hydrogenase to an electrode surface, and considerable progress has been made in the synthesis of compounds in solution resembling the hydrogenase active site and showing enhanced activity for hydrogen evolution [124,148–150,213]. Also some supports with excellent electrical conductivity have been investigated to improve the electrical contact to the active sites of MoS2. Generally, carbon materials are commonly used as electrocatalyst supports for the HER and other electrochemical applications, mainly including carbon nanotubes, macroporous–meosporous carbon materials, graphene, reduced graphene oxide sheets, and so on [151–155,214].

4.2.3. By increasing the amount of edges The other approach to improving the electrocatalytic activity of MoS2 is to increase the amount of edges per mole MoS2 [219]. Tsai et al. have used DFT to study the support effects of MoS2 and different catalyst supports on the hydrogen adsorption free energy at the MoS2 Mo-edge and S-edge sites, the details are present in Fig. 33 [218]. They found a general trend for the Mo-edge that strong adhesion of the MoS2 catalyst onto the support leads to weaker hydrogen binding. For the S-edge, a competing effect where strong support interactions simultaneously strengthen the edge reconstruction while weakening the S H bond, leading to hydrogen adsorption free energies that are relatively unchanged. The calculated detail hydrogen adsorption free energies and the MoS2 adhesion energies on different supports for the Mo-edge and S-edge are summarized in Table 2.
Two examples of the effect of increasing the amount of edges by graphene were recently published. In the one by Li et al. [111] MoS2 nanocrystals were deposited on graphene by a hydrothermal reduction, using hydrazine, of both ammonium tetrathiomolybdate ((NH4)2MoS4), and the oxidized graphene. The composite is a material with an abundance of small MoS2 crystals dispersed on the conductive graphene. The other example was shown by Chang et al. [220], they report that the graphene sheets grown on Ni foams provide robust protection and efficiently increase their stability in acid. The highly conductive 3D graphene/Ni foam structure also effectively increases the catalyst loading, leading to the enhancement in electrocatalytic HER efficiency. The graphene sheets grown on Ni foams provide robust protection and efficiently increase its stability in acid. The hydrogen volution rate reaches 302 ml g−1 cm−2 h−1 (13.47 mmol g−1 cm−2 h−1) at an overpotential of V = 0.2 V and the catalytic species were likely related to the bridging S22− or apical S2−. The developments in graphene-based 3D electrodes may further advance the efficiency of various electrocatalytic reactions, which warrants more investigations.
The general principle governing the amount of edges is a function of how the relative surface energy of the edges compares to the basal plane. The surface energy of the MoS2 edges is reported to be 100 times larger than the basal plane surface energy (250 mJ/m2). In order to increase the amount of edges, the edge surface energy should be lowered compared to the basal plane surface energy. A recent study show that if MoS2 is synthesized in an ionic liquid, the resulting material is a porous structure comprising of randomly packed, and almost exclusively single sheets of MoS2 [160]. The ionic liquid is chosen so as to match the surface tension of the MoS2 edges. The synthesized MoS2 materials show great promise as highly active HER catalysts and are an excellent example of a promising approach to increase the number of edges on the catalyst. Also Lukowski et al. first synthesized flowerlike MoS2 nanostructures with a high density of exposed edges directly on graphite substrates via a simple chemical vapor deposition method starting from MoCl5 and elemental sulfur precursors, also they demonstrated such a simple and rational method to provide a significant enhancement of the electrocatalytic performance of MoS2 using chemical exfoliation, which offers two advantages: (i) the dense MoS2 flakes are dominated by edges (Fig. 1a), thus increasing the density of active sites, and (ii) the direct growth on conductive graphite substrates results in high-quality, low-electrical-loss contact to the 3D nanostructured electrocatalyst [156]. Yu et al. [221] have quantitatively demonstrated the layerdependent electrocatalysis of MoS2 materials and elucidated that the layer dependence is rooted in the interlayer hopping of electrons. Different from conventional wisdom, which believes that the edge site is catalytically active, their results suggest that the atoms in the basal plane can be active sites as well as shown in Fig. 35, which shows the nice consistency suggests a dominant role of the electron hopping in the layer-dependent electrocatalysis of MoS2. The better catalytic performance of the edge sites could be because the edge site may provide an easier path for the hopping of electrons than the atoms in the basal plane. The result points out that increasing the hopping efficiency of electrons is a key for the rational design of MoS2 materials with optimal catalytic activities. The efficiency of hopping is determined by the interlayer coupling of electron orbitals [28,170]. Therefore, strategies that can increase the interlayer coupling, such as intercalation of metal ions or atoms, are expected able to enhance the electrocatalytic performance of MoS2 materials.
Most recently, Li et al. verified that strained S-vacancies in the basal plane of 2H-phase monolayer MoS2 act as a new highly active and tunable catalytic site for HER, and the hydrogen adsorption free energy ( GH) can be further manipulated by straining the surface with S-vacancies, which fine-tunes the catalytic activity [222]. Proper combinations of S-vacancy and strain yield the optimal GH = 0 eV, which allows to achieve the highest intrinsic HER activity among MoS2-based catalysts.
4.3. MoS2 and their composite as photocatalyst for HER
4.3.1. Overview of MoS2 photocatalytic HER MoS2 alone has negligible photocatalytic activity despite the fact that bulk MoS2 has an indirect absorbance edge at about 1040 nm, which seems ideal for solar light harvesting [223,224]. Two strategies also have been proposed to improve the photocatalytic HER catalytic activity of MoS2: (i) increase light response ability and (ii) promote the charge transport.
4.3.2. By increasing light response ability MoS2 using as photocatalytic hydrogen production, often undergoes modification and combines with other narrow bandgap semiconductors to increase the light response ability. Pt, Au and Ag were known as an extremely efficient electrocatalyst for HER and it is usually the first co-catalyst choice in the modification photocatalysis as light response centre [30,34,225–229]. By promoting the charge transport In this part, we take graphene and reduced graphene oxide rGO) for instance, which could be served as electron channel paths nd active adsorption sites for promoting the charge transport. s many research, graphene and reduced graphene oxide (rGO) ave been incorporated with semiconductors to form heterostrucures to improve the catalytic activity in either photocatalysis or lectrocatalysis [238–243]. ithout noble metals. Jaroniec synthesized of TiO2 NPs on a layred MoS2/graphene (MG) hybrid for use in photocatalytic H2 roduction [244]. Even without a noble-metal co-catalyst, the iO2/MoS2/graphene composite reaches a high H2 production rate f 165.3 mol h−1 when the content of the MoS2/graphene coatalyst is 0.5 wt% and the content of graphene in this co-catalyst s 5.0 wt%, and the apparent quantum efficiency reaches 9.7% at 65 nm. the CB of TiO2 can be transferred to MoS2 nanosheets through the graphene sheets (which act as a conductive electron transport “highway”) and then react with the adsorbed H+ ions at the edges of MoS2 to form H2. This indicates that because of a notable synergetic effect between MoS2 nanosheets and graphene, the composite co-catalyst has several advantages, including suppression of charge recombination, improvement of interfacial charge transfer, and an increase in the number of active adsorption sites and photocatalytic reaction centers. In addition, some photogenerated electrons can also be transferred directly to the MoS2 nanosheets on the surface of TiO2 or to C atoms on the graphene sheets, after which reaction with H+ to produce H2 is possible. This study demonstrates that the layered composite material (MoS2/graphene here) can be used as an effective co-catalyst for photocatalytic water splitting, which is a valuable indication for further development of related composite materials as substitutes for Pt in photocatalytic H2 production.
Recently, Eosin Y dye and the MoS2 NPs have been codeposited on the rGO nanosheets to form a photocatalyst by Wu group [245]. The UV–visible absorption spectra and hydrogen generated abilities of pure MoS2, the MoS2/rGO, and the pMoS2/n-rGO photocatalysts are present in Fig. 38. However, the MoS2–rGO system shows no photocatalytic activity in the absence of a photosensitizer (Eosin Y dye), which indicates that MoS2 provides reaction sites for HER. MoS2 has a layered S–Mo–S structure, which has extremely low conductivity between adjacent S–Mo–S layers, leading to poor charge mobility. And in MoS2–rGO or MoS2@ Graphene system, Graphene and rGO were always considered as a passive component that provided a channel for charge transport, not help with the charge generation as shown in Fig. 39. The geometry will also increase the contact area. The increased contact area will promote the charge transfer at the interface. In addition, the rGO will be doped with nitrogen to form a n-type semiconductor as a support to grow the p-type MoS2 nanoplatelets, forming many nanoscale p–n junctions on each rGO nanosheet. The space charge layer created by the nanoscale p–n junctions will not only suppress the charge recombination but also enhance the photogeneration of electron–hole pairs. As a result, the nanoscale p–n junction increases the photocatalytic activity toward HER. They introduced an effective method to improve the HER photocatalysis of semiconductors without sacrificing environmental sustainability by incorporating precious metals or toxic co-catalysts. In that paper, a thin nanoplateles structure of MoS2 was fabricated to create a large percentage of edge sites. This nanoplatelet structure could shorten the distance that photogenerated charge carriers diffuse to the reaction sites, lowering the charge recombination loss that usually occurs during volume diffusion.
It is also should be noted here, impressive photocurrents could be achieved by loading hydrophobic [Mo3S4]4+ onto vertically aligned pillars of p-doped Si [246]. The incomplete cubane-type cluster [Mo3S4]4+ efficiently catalytic the evolution of hydrogen when coupled to a p-type Si semiconductor that harvests red photons in the solar spectrum. The prototype representative, that is, the incomplete cubane-type cluster [Mo3S4]4+ has been in focus but is otherwise representative of the broader class of homologous heterometallic cubane-type clusters. Once the observed electrocatalytic stability issue has been rectified, this class may offer new prospects for enhance the electrochemical and photoelectrocatalytic HER performances [246,247].

metadata.abstractText: In this review, we provide a comprehensive overview of the MoS2 nanomaterials, summarizing recent related studies on structures, properties, synthesis techniques and recent progress on hydrogen evolution reaction (HER). Base on its crystalline anisotropy arising from the sandwiched structure of S–Mo–S layers, four poly-types of MoS2 structures have been identified, viz. 1T MoS2, 1H MoS2, 2H MoS2 and 3R MoS2.
